head.title: Renewing the Dance of Martha Graham

identified-content.org: Graham, Martha, Center for Contemporary Dance

hedline.hl1: Renewing the Dance of Martha Graham

abstract.p: Editorial deplores dispute over control over Martha Graham's dance legacy that has forced Martha Grham Dance Co to suspend operations; says principals must get together and produce an agreement that guarantees Ron Protas the income his rights to Graham's works was designed to produce, as well as the right of Martha Graham Center to oversee her aesthetic legacy as only it can

block.p: In most artists' lives, there is a tension between making new work and trying to control the work they have already made. There is no better example than the American dancer and choreographer Martha Graham, who died in 1991. Graham's legacy is now deadlocked. In March, after months of friction, the board of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance dismissed Ron Protas, the legal heir to Graham's work, as artistic director and a board member. In turn, Mr. Protas has refused to allow the Martha Graham Dance Company to stage her works, though he has licensed them to other performing groups. This week, in response, the Martha Graham Dance Company issued a public letter, signed by nearly every notable person in the dance world, urging other companies not to perform Graham's works until the company reaches agreement with Mr. Protas. Because of this turmoil and the inability to raise funds in such circumstances, the board of the Martha Graham Center has suspended operations.

In life, Graham was a tumultuous, deeply controlling figure, and sadly, this crisis is largely of her own making. The gift of her work to Mr. Protas, who was a devoted aide to Graham late in her life but not a dancer himself, was more than generous. It may also have been unwise. Mr. Protas has been a fierce defender of Graham's legacy. He had agreed to step aside from the Martha Graham Center and to license Graham's works to her company for $1 a year, but found it impossible to relinquish control. He has alienated the board, the dancers, dance presenters around the world and donors who would support Graham's legacy.

There is no better example than the American dancer and choreographer Martha Graham, who died in 1991. Graham's legacy is now deadlocked. In March, after months of friction, the board of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance dismissed Ron Protas, the legal heir to Graham's work, as artistic director and a board member. In turn, Mr. Protas has refused to allow the Martha Graham Dance Company to stage her works, though he has licensed them to other performing groups. This week, in response, the Martha Graham Dance Company issued a public letter, signed by nearly every notable person in the dance world, urging other companies not to perform Graham's works until the company reaches agreement with Mr. Protas. Because of this turmoil and the inability to raise funds in such circumstances, the board of the Martha Graham Center has suspended operations.

In life, Graham was a tumultuous, deeply controlling figure, and sadly, this crisis is largely of her own making. The gift of her work to Mr. Protas, who was a devoted aide to Graham late in her life but not a dancer himself, was more than generous. It may also have been unwise. Mr. Protas has been a fierce defender of Graham's legacy. He had agreed to step aside from the Martha Graham Center and to license Graham's works to her company for $1 a year, but found it impossible to relinquish control. He has alienated the board, the dancers, dance presenters around the world and donors who would support Graham's legacy.

This is an artistic tragedy. Graham's work is too important to be locked away from the public by a dispute over control. What is clearly needed is a way of bringing the principals together and producing an agreement that guarantees Mr. Protas the income his right in these works was designed to produce, as well as the right of the Martha Graham Center to oversee her aesthetic legacy as only it can. Everyone in this sad story is determined to preserve Graham's work, to ensure that it continues to matter in the years ahead. That should be grounds enough for resolving this dispute.
